_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Covington Wastewater Treatment Plant (CWWTP) has chlorine on site that requires protection as defined under Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  The City of Covington, TN, has implemented a PSM program to provide information to employees to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling and processing of highly hazardous materials.  The program emphasizes the application of management controls and standard operating procedures when addressing the risks associated with handling or working near highly hazardous chemicals.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) summarizes the worst case scenarios for a release of chlorine, the management systems and monitoring systems in place to prevent such a release, and the training and employee participation in the PSM program.

The CWWTP treats and disposes of all sanitary waste discharged to the City Sewer System.  The facility utilizes 1-ton cylinders to treat the wastewater in the chlorination room.  Three cylinders are always connected to the chlorination system and as many as three cylinders are stored as a backup. The CWWTP also uses sulfur dioxide cylinders to treat their wastewater but maintains an inventory of less than 5,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide, which is below the threshold for RMP reporting. 

The RMP calculates that the worst case scenario for a release involving the storage of chlorine would be caused by vandalism of all the chlorine cylinders in the chlorine room.  Because only three of the cylinders are connected at a time, a process failure could only release no more than 6,000 pounds of chlorine.  Vandalism or terrorist activities could cause the release of chlorine from all cylinders, potentially releasing 12,000 pounds of chlorine. The worst-case release scenario is further detailed below.  EPA?s RMP Comp was used in the consequence analysis.

Worst Case
Chemical and Amount Released: 12,000 pounds of chlorine in 10 minutes inside the Chlorin

e Room of the Maintenance Building
Weather Conditions:77 ?F with a 3.4 mph wind in Class F atmospheric stability

This release would impact the area around the CWWTP within 2.5 mile radius and affect 1,700 people, churches and multiple industries. Security systems around the property would prevent the vandalism from occurring and chlorine detection sensors would notify emergency responders of the release. The emergency responders would use water spray to prevent the chlorine cloud from travelling significant distances. 

The alternate release scenario is more plausible than the worst case scenario, but measures are in place to prevent and mitigate such a release.  The alternate release scenario involves the simultaneous failure of a piece of chlorine handling equipment (piping, valve, etc) and the vacuum breaker or damage to just one chlorine cylinder.  The vacuum breaker is designed to fail shut if a leak in the lines develops. If the vacuum breaker fails open (sticks) and a leak develops in the piping, chlorine would be released into the Chlorine Room. The leak would be detected by the chlorine monitoring system, and facility personnel or the Covington Fire Department would be able to respond quickly and shut off the cylinder at the main cylinder valve. 

Alternate Case
Chemical and Amount Released: 2,000 pounds of chlorine in 10 minutes inside the Chlorine Room of the Maintenace Building
Weather Conditions:77 ?F with a 6.7 mph wind in Class D atmospheric stability

This release would impact the area around the CWWTP within 0.2 mile radius and affect less than 10 people at one industry. 

The CWWTP is in compliance with OSHA PSM and emergency action plan regulations, as well as the EPCRA Section 302 rules.  The regularly scheduled maintenance program is key to maintaining the CWWTP in good condition.  There have been no accidental releases at the CWWTP during the last five years.

Should there be a significant chlorine release, the Covington Fire Department (CFD)

will respond. The CFD has several trained Hazardous Material technicians that can handle any accidental chlorine release.  The CFD provides emergency response training to CWWTP personnel.  Should the need for an evacuation occur, the Covington Police Department (CPD) will notify all households identified within the 2.5 mile radius downwind of the release. 

Annual waste water operator certification and continuing education maintains and continually improves safety at the CWWTP.
